item.title: Amazon Luna Expands in Europe, Signs Multi-Year Deal with EA
item.content:encoded:
https://wccftech.com/amazon-luna-expands-in-europe-signs-multi-year-deal-with-ea/

Today, Amazon Luna announced its further expansion into European territory. The games cloud streaming service is now available in Sweden, Portugal, Belgium, and Luxembourg. Amazon Luna was already available in the United States, Austria, Canada, Germany, Italy, France, Spain, The Netherlands, Poland, and the United Kingdom. Additionally, Amazon Luna unveiled a multi-year content partnership with Electronic Arts to bring the publisher's games to the cloud platform.

Mustafa Hakim, General Manager of Amazon Luna, said in a statement:

We‚Äôre delighted to bring Amazon Luna to even more players in Europe so they can conveniently access the games they love wherever they are, on their preferred devices. We are also thrilled to partner with Electronic Arts to bring great games, including player favorites from the EA SPORTS portfolio, soon to our customers. Luna is committed to making gaming easier, more fun, affordable, and accessible for everyone. We have an exciting year ahead of us and we look forward to sharing more soon.

David Tinson, EVP and Chief Experiences Officer of Electronic Arts, added:

Our teams are focused on building experiences that entertain and engage EA‚Äôs massive online communities, and we‚Äôre excited to partner with Amazon to make those games available to even more people. We look forward to a selection of EA games joining Amazon Luna, offering new ways for players and fans to come together across a variety of devices they already own, wherever they are.

Starting today, Luna+ subscribers can access Star Wars Jedi: Survivor, Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order, and Dead Space, with more games coming soon. By the way, wherever Luna is available, Amazon Prime members get ongoing access to Fortnite, LEGO Fortnite, Rocket Racing, Trackmania, and a rotating monthly selection of games on Luna at no additional cost. Until 31 March, Prime members can play WRC Generations, Overcooked! 2, Spitlings, The Jackbox Party Pack 3, and Strange Horticulture, with new titles coming in April.

item.title: That Pac-Man, but what if he was a little bit evil, Metroidvania now has a summer release date
item.content:encoded:
https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/that-pac-man-but-what-if-he-was-a-little-bit-evil-metroidvania-now-has-a-summer-release-date

Remember Secret Level, that Amazon show that came out last December? I wouldn't blame you if you already forgot about it, for the most part it was pretty forgettable considering how much of it could be boiled down to "damn‚Ä¶ video games are violent, huh?", except positioning that as universally cool, actually (let's leave that whole conversation there). Easily the weirdest of all the episodes was the Pac-Man one, given that it was only Pac-Man in the sense that there was a floating yellow orb thing that kind of looks like the titular, iconic video game character.

Really, though, it's about some humanoid alien being told to eat everything it comes across by this orb, called Puck (get it?), resulting in something that's admittedly intriguingly alarming and grotesque, but also has such ridiculously high levels of edgy animated short film from the early days of YouTube energy. Three days after this episode came out, there came the surprise reveal that this episode is getting a Metroidvania video game adaptation called Shadow Labyrinth, for reasons I couldn't begin to understand.

And now, thanks to the powers that be at Nintendo during today's Direct, a release date has been confirmed for the confusing game: July 18th. The release date announcement came with a snazzy new trailer that revealed you also get a mech? Honestly, the whole thing is unheard of levels of silly, I'm still struggling to believe that this is a real game that's been greenlit, but hey ho, perhaps we've got a new Hollow Knight on our hands.

Still can't quite tell if the story will be the exact same as the Secret Level episode, there's some big discrepancies (and a much bigger Nier: Automata vibe to it), so we'll all just have to wait a few more months to find out.

item.title: Metal Gear Solid Snake Eater Remake Will Fix One Of The Most Annoying Features Of The Original
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/metal-gear-solid-3-snake-eater-camo-feature-new-1851772814

I‚Äôm just gonna level with ya‚Äôll, I didn‚Äôt think much of Metal Gear Solid 3: Snake Eater in 2004. But a new look at an improved gameplay feature in the upcoming remake, Metal Gear Solid Delta, might just be enough to convert this jaded fan who‚Äôs convinced the series peaked at Sons of Liberty. In a 12-second clip, Naked Snake can be seen swapping his camo from a foresty look to something more suitable for an urban environment in record time. It‚Äôs way faster and less cumbersome-looking than the camo-swapping of the original. Check it out:

Hell yeah, that‚Äôs a whole three seconds to swap camo with an in-game menu that looks pretty snappy. The original required you to pause the game, then select ‚Äúcamouflage‚Äù from a menu, then select ‚Äúface‚Äù or ‚Äúuniform‚Äù before choosing your desired pattern.

As I said earlier, at best I feel sorta ‚Äúmeh‚Äù about MGS3; the menu-diving the original demands of you to swap camo, eat anything, and treat your wounds is one of its biggest offenders in my opinion (alongside the boring, self-indulgent story and that god awful song). I found it very hard to stay engaged in the action when the game made me sort through menu screens so often, despite the camo being a genuinely neat idea.

Metal Gear Solid 4: Guns of the Patriots notably eschewed the whole eating and wound-healing stuff (for the better). It would keep the camo, though. And since it took place many decades after MGS3, there was a sci-fi twist on it that made things much smoother. In MGS4, Old Snake could just lean against almost any wall and absorb the texture via his nifty OctoCamo which, it turns out, was inspired by the natural camouflage abilities of real-life octopi.

The natural ability of octopi was also referenced in MGS4 via the game‚Äôs opening faux TV ads.

While some of us might be a little skeptical of this post-Kojima MGS future we‚Äôre entering with Delta, it‚Äôs nice to see Konami looking for opportunities to improve existing aspects of the game. Here‚Äôs hoping eating and wound-healing will be just as speedy in the remake, which arrives on PS5, Xbox Series X/S, and PC on August 28, 2025.

item.title: Black Ops 6 Season 3 Introduces New Multiplayer Maps, Modes and More
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/black-ops-6-season-3-introduces-new-multiplayer-maps-modes-and-more/

Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 Season 3 roadmap has revealed new multiplayer maps, modes, additional equipment, and multiplayer ranked play changes. 

Black Ops 6 Season 3 Maps

In Black Ops 6 season 3, players can check out five new maps and a variant. Barrage is a 6v6 medium-sized Core map set in 1968 Vietnam. Nomad is a 6v6/2v2 small-sized Strike map where players battle in the ruins of a fortified settlement. 

Next up is the return of the fan-favourite map, Firing Range. Black Ops 6 Season 3 has received a remastered version of Firing Range, a 6v6, medium-sized Core map that finally returned to the series after Black Ops 4 in 2018. Next is Haven, a 6v6, medium-sized core map set in a KGB Safehouse in 1991. 

Last up is Signal, which is again a 6v6/2v2, small-sized Strike Map. Players start their battles from opposing submarine bays while going through the Control room of an ocean rig numbers station. Additionally, a Nuketown variant called Blazetown will be released for a limited time mid-season. 

Black Ops 6 Season 3 Multiplayer Modes

Coming to the new multiplayer game modes revealed in the Black Ops 6 Season 3 Roadmap, players will see the return of two classic modes, Sharpshooter and Demolition. There‚Äôs also a limited-time mode called Joint Operators.

Sharpshooter is a free-for-all party mode where every player needs to use the same loadout, and it changes every 45 seconds. Every time it changes, you will receive a new primary weapon, secondary Weapon, dedicated melee weapon, tactical equipment and lethal equipment. 

In Demolition, players will alternate between attacking and defensive positions across two bomb sites. The attacking team wins when it destroys the bomb and receives a time bonus for the first detonation. All the players from the attacking team spawn with bombs, and there are multiple respawns for both teams. 

In Joint Operators, players need to test their skills in a gauntlet of five Core mode variants in a single match: Head Stash (TDM), Inhalation (Domination), Hotbox (Hardpoint), Very High Target (HVT), and Munchies (Kill Confirmed). The modes will include some modifiers, too, like double health, low gravity, hallucinations and third-person POV. 

Black Ops 6 Season 3 Perks

Black Ops 6 Season 3 Roadmap reveals additional equipment, such as two new perks and a scorestreak. 

Close Shave is an Enforcer type Perk, which automatically uses the player‚Äôs Dedicated Melee attack when they perform a weapon butt attack. Vendetta is a Recon-type perk that arrives mid-season. When the player respawns, it makes their killer‚Äôs last known location for a short duration‚Äîbonus points for exacting revenge. Death Machine is the new Lethal type Scorestreak. 

Black Ops 6 Season 3 Multiplayer Ranked Changes

Lastly, Black Ops 6 Season 3 roadmap has revealed new changes and additions for Multiplayer Ranked Play. Players can take their competitiveness to the next level as the same settings, maps, modes, and weapon restrictions used by the Call of Duty League have been added to the game. Winning matches rewards players with SR (Skill Rating), and progressing through the ranks will reward players with Rank Skins and Win Challenge rewards. 

Moreover, the developers have added Retroactive SR Adjustments to reverse the impact of cheaters. When a Ranked Cheater is banned, any players that lost against them will be refunded their SR. Also, a new feature has been added that lets you rejoin Ranked Matches if they were disconnected. However, players need to rejoin within 5 minutes. Check out Ranked Play rewards and Weapon Blueprints here. 

In other news, Verdansk will launch with a ‚Äòcasual mode‚Äô that has 120 bots. Also, Zombies is getting a new map in Season 3. What are your thoughts on Black Ops 6, maps, modes, and all the other content? Let us know in the comments or on our community forum!

item.title: Wuchang: Fallen Feathers ‚Äì The First Hands-on Preview
item.content:encoded:
https://www.ign.com/articles/wuchang-fallen-feathers-the-first-hands-on-preview

In a space as crowded as the soulslike genre, it can be difficult to stand out, but after two hours with the uber-difficult Wuchang: Fallen Feathers, it seems the folks at Leenzee Games may be onto something. Taking place in a magical reimagining of dynastic China, you play a pirate warrior who has some serious moves, making use of intricate and deadly spells, an arsenal of weapons with potent movesets, and an upgrade tree that‚Äôs much more involved than your typical action-adventure game. This makes for an adventure where, more often than not, I felt like the scary badass the rest of the world should be afraid of, rather than the other way around. Of course, the upper limit on just how much I could make myself feel like an overpowered Dynasty Warriors character was my own skill level and understanding of Wuchang‚Äôs extremely complex systems, which I could only dive so deep with during my limited demo. But what I‚Äôve seen so far has me quite optimistic.

The main way Wuchang: Fallen Feathers seems to differentiate itself from its peers is that here, instead of a few basic sword moves, a handful of meager spells and abilities, and a tiny health bar, you‚Äôre given a pretty extensive toolkit of formidable tools to play with. Each weapon allows you to unleash unique flurries of attacks that send you soaring into the air, darting across the map, and performing insane feats of dexterity that are far beyond what‚Äôs possible in most soulslikes. It got to the point where I felt like the area boss stomping my enemies flat, rather than a scared, cautious adventurer facing incredible odds.

That feeling of superiority might have something to do with how those abilities are acquired: by harvesting them from fallen enemies. That‚Äôs right! Every defeated foe is more than just a handful of upgrade materials. You actually get to learn their moves and put them to use against future opponents, eventually turning you into a deadly reflection of everyone you‚Äôve bested in battle, and in my time with it I already began to feel like a power-stealing badass in short order. And this was just the opening areas of the adventure too ‚Äì I can only imagine how wild things get later on when you‚Äôre squaring off against more powerful opponents and presumably unlocking even more insane abilities.

I can only imagine how wild things get later on when you‚Äôre squaring off against more powerful opponents and presumably unlocking even more insane abilities.

Don‚Äôt get me wrong: there were still plenty of instances where my eagerness or lack of awareness got me absolutely smashed to pieces, but I also felt like I had way more options for cutting the enemy down to size. For example, one move I was given while wielding a giant ax let me leap straight into the air to ludicrous anime-level heights, then smash down on my opponent, stomping them flat and leaving a minion-shaped impression in the earth. Another weapon, fast moving dual blades, gave me the ability to fire off a bunch of small, sticky explosives every time I dodged, which then exploded doing a small amount of damage, but more importantly, interrupting enemy movement.

These abilities and weapon combos, combined with spells that let me do things like fire off a deadly disc of fire, allowed me to play much more aggressively than I‚Äôm accustomed to, and it‚Äôs clear there‚Äôs just a whole lot more to learn with Wuchang in general. I didn‚Äôt have nearly enough time to fully wrap my mind around the various skill trees, ability customization options that let me alter how my weapons functioned, and spellcasting system, but it‚Äôs clear this borrows quite a bit from RPGs and will need to be thought through if you want to max out your levels of badassery.

That will be pretty helpful to do too, because of the two bosses I took on in Wuchang, one of them was extremely aggressive and equally beefed up with fancy movesets. It took me quite a few tries to learn her quick, convoluted attack patterns, and master the timing for parrying her attacks, especially in the second half of the fight when each swipe of her blade sent out massive gusts of wind that knocked my on my butt and did way more damage than I thought the wind was capable of. Eventually, though, I stood triumphant against her devilish tricks. Rather than a feeble goon hopelessly outmatched by an enemy clearly above my power level, Wuchang‚Äôs boss fights made me feel a lot more like a peer locked in a duel with strong weapons and destructive abilities to see who was more worthy of success.

If there‚Äôs one part I didn‚Äôt get a completely strong read on, it‚Äôs Wuchang‚Äôs story, which centers on a disease spreading throughout the lands that drives people mad and makes them sprout feathers. I didn‚Äôt see enough to say whether or not this is likely to go the distance, but I will say I‚Äôve lost count of the number of soulslikes in the past few years that have leaned on that incredibly tired trope. I get that having a disease that turns people into monsters offers a pretty easy reason to make everything in the world want to kill you, which is very helpful in this kind of game, but man am I ever tired of seeing it. I‚Äôd really like to see Wuchang break free from some of the story cliches in the same way it seems to be switching things up when it comes to combat style.

I get that having a disease that turns people into monsters offers a pretty easy reason to make everything in the world want to kill you, which is very helpful in this kind of game, but man am I ever tired of seeing it.

It‚Äôs also worth noting just how visually impressive Wuchang is, which is by no means the norm for the genre. Even if I was dying half a dozen times to the same boss or lost among a sea of disgusting, mutated enemies, I was at least able to content myself with how downright gorgeous everything looked, ruined and deeply troubling as the world was. That said, I did notice somewhat long load times after each humiliating defeat that respawned me back at a checkpoint, and I have to wonder how much of that hang time is owed to the world and characters looking so dang good. In fairness, there‚Äôs very little chance this thing‚Äôs been optimized enough to be representative of the final product, but since I was playing on a PC that seemed fairly powerful, it‚Äôs definitely something I‚Äôm going to want to keep an eye on as I check out future builds.

With only a short exploration area and two boss fights to contend with, I only caught a small glimpse at Wuchang: Fallen Feathers, but I already feel pretty good about its chances at being more than just another soulslike to add to the ridiculously overflowing pile. The movesets are intricate and interesting, the RPG mechanics seem deep and offer a lot of freedom (even if I can‚Äôt claim to understand some of them fully), and the boss fights gave me a serious run for my money that‚Äôs rare these days. All that‚Äôs already got me pretty excited to play more.

item.title: The Pok√©mon Company Addresses TCG Shortages and Scalpers Following Destined Rivals Launch in New Statement
item.content:encoded:
https://www.ign.com/articles/the-pokmon-company-addresses-tcg-shortages-and-scalpers-following-destined-rivals-launch-in-new-statement

Company "actively working" to print more of the impacted sets.

The Pok√©mon Company has officially addressed issues fans have had with getting their hands on recent Pok√©mon Trading Card Game sets. In a new statement, the company affirmed there would be reprints on the way, and that it's working to get products to fans.

The release of the latest set for the Pok√©mon TCG, Destined Rivals, saw a combination of problems in shortages, reported issues with pre-orders, and of course, scalpers. Several other recent sets, including Prismatic Evolutions and the Blooming Waters box, have also been incredibly in-demand, and thus, difficult to acquire.

Pok√©mon TCG: Scarlet & Violet - Destined Rivals Pok√©mon Center Elite Trainer Box Images

In a statement posted to the Pok√©mon site, TPC said it is aware that some fans are "experiencing difficulties purchasing certain Pok√©mon Trading Card game (TCG) products due to very high demand impacting availability."

"We understand this inconvenience can be disappointing for fans, and we are actively working to print more of the impacted Pok√©mon TCG products as quickly as possible and at maximum capacity to acknowledge this," the statement read. "Reprinted products are expected to be available at participating retailers as soon as possible."

TPC also said it will be "maximizing production" for future TCG expansions to increase product availability at launch, and will "continue to reprint impacted products" to replenish stock, including for the Pok√©mon Center.

Additionally, The Pok√©mon Company addressed some of its scalper response in a roundabout manner. As the company put it, for releases on the Pok√©mon Center, it is "committed to providing a smooth purchasing experience and employ technology that helps get products into the hands of fans first and foremost." Currently, the Pokemon Center uses a virtual queue for some products during periods of increased site traffic.

"We will continue to explore measures that help create the best possible experience for Pok√©mon Center customers," the company said. "We‚Äôd like to thank the community for their continued support and patience as we work to deliver more Pok√©mon TCG products to fans."

Hopefully, this statement holds true and we see some changes to make collecting and playing the Pok√©mon TCG a little less stressful when a new set arrives.

item.title: Gundam: The Witch From Mercury Makes Series Debut in Super Robot Wars Y
item.content:encoded:
https://www.ign.com/articles/gundam-the-witch-from-mercury-makes-series-debut-in-super-robot-wars-y

Plus units from G Gundam, Code Geass, Aura Battler Dunbine, and more.

A new Super Robot Wars is on the way, and it's adding a popular Gundam to the mix. Super Robot Wars Y has been officially announced for PlayStation 5, Nintendo Switch, and PC via Steam, and it'll see Suletta Mercury from Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch From Mercury make her series debut.

Announced today during the March 2025 Nintendo Direct, the latest Super Robot Wars wasn't shown in the English broadcast, but did appear in Nintendo's Japanese stream. Regardless, Super Robot Wars Y is planned for reelase in the West, arriving sometime in 2025.

If you're unfamilar, Super Robot Wars is a long-running tactical RPG series that mashes up mecha and robot from across many different series. While the heavy-hitters like Mobile Suit Gundam, Mazinger, Macross, and more are all seen throughout the series, you'll also see the occassional outside-shot like Cowboy Bebop or Magic Knight Rayearth.

This entry marks Gundam: The Witch From Mercury's Super Robot Wars debut, putting Suletta alongside a legion of past Gundam pilots appearing in the new title. Alongside G-Witch, Bandai Namco highlights a few other series making appearances in Super Robot Wars Y:

  • Combattler V
  • Aura Battler Dunbine
  • Mobile Fighter G Gundam
  • Majestic Prince
  • Macross Delta: Passionate Wakure
  • Code Geass Lelouch of the Re;surrection
  • Getter Robo Arc

Spearheading development is Bandai Namco Forge Digitals, formerly known as B.B. Studio, which has worked on the past Super Robot Wars games.

No date has been set yet, but Super Robot Wars Y is targeting a 2025 release for PS5, Switch, and PC.

Be sure to check out our round-up of everything announced at the March 2025 Nintendo Direct to catch anything else you might have missed in the showcase.

I don't think I've seen gamers this happy in a long while.

Man, if you want to see some wild expressions of pure joy, find yourself a video game community that's been neglected for years, never expected to get another entry in their series of choice, but was surprised with one anyway. Today, that's the Tomodachi Life community, who are celebrating all over social media in the wake of the announcement of Tomodachi Life: Living the Dream today at the Nintendo Direct.

Seriously, I don't think I've seen gamers this happy in a long time. Across Twitter/X, Bluesky, Reddit, and other social platforms, Tomodachi Life lovers are having the time of their lives, and making the memes to prove it. Here's just a small sample of the many, many, MANY celebrations to make your day:

One segment of the community is especially excited by what they see as a tease of a long-awaited feature in Tomodachi Life: same-sex relationships. Way, way back in 2014, Nintendo issued a formal apology to fans of the game for not including same-sex relationships, saying that it was "not possible" to change the game's design so drastically after launch by implementing them in a patch. However, Nintendo also said, "We pledge that if we create a next installment in the Tomodachi series, we will strive to design a game-play experience from the ground up that is more inclusive, and better represents all players.‚Äù

At the end of Tomodachi Life: Living the Dream's trailer today, there was a brief encounter between two women that some fans are interpreting as a tease that Nintendo is about to fulfill its promise to fans.

Tomodachi Life: Living the Dream was Nintendo's "one more thing" game announcement from today's Nintendo Direct. Though it's not coming out until 2026, we did get a brief look at the return of the Mii-filled community and some of the types of relationships and interactions we might see on the island paradise where they live. It's been ten years since the last Tomodachi Life game, and many fans of the game had given up hope that the series would ever see a revival, especially as Nintendo moved away from using Miis as part of its platform experience.

Congratulations, Tomodachi Life lovers. You earned this one.

item.title: Embattled Ubisoft Forms Subsidiary for IPs Like Assassin's Creed, Far Cry and Rainbow Six With the Help of ‚Ç¨1.16 Billion Tencent Investment
item.content:encoded:

Ubisoft has created a subsidiary company based on its Assassin‚Äôs Creed, Far Cry, and Tom Clancy‚Äôs Rainbow Six brands, with a ‚Ç¨1.16 billion (approx. $1.25 billion) investment from Chinese megacorp Tencent.

The news comes hot on the heels of the launch of Assassin's Creed Shadows, which just passed the 3 million player mark. Ubisoft suffered a number of high-profile flops, layoffs, studio closures, and game cancellations in the run up to Assassin's Creed Shadows' release, and there is enormous pressure on it to succeed after the company's share price hit an historic low.

Ubisoft said this new subsidiary, valued at ‚Ç¨4 billion (approx. $4.3 billion) and based in France, will focus on ‚Äúbuilding game ecosystems designed to become truly evergreen and multi-platform.‚Äù Tencent‚Äôs stake amounts to 25%.

Ubisoft added: ‚ÄúBacked by greater investment and boosted creative capacities, it will drive further increases in quality of narrative solo experiences, expand multiplayer offerings with increased frequency of content release, introduce free-to-play touchpoints, and integrate more social features.‚Äù

Ubisoft said it will ‚Äúfocus‚Äù on the development of its Ghost Recon and The Division franchises and grow its top performing games.

‚ÄúToday Ubisoft is opening a new chapter in its history,‚Äù said Yves Guillemot, co-founder and chief executive officer of Ubisoft.

‚ÄúAs we accelerate the company‚Äôs transformation, this is a foundational step in changing Ubisoft‚Äôs operating model that will enable us to be both agile and ambitious. We are focused on building strong game ecosystems designed to become evergreen, growing high-performing brands and creating new IPs powered by cutting-edge and emerging technologies.

‚ÄúWith the creation of a dedicated subsidiary that will spearhead development for three of our largest franchises and the onboarding of Tencent as a minority investor, we are crystalizing the value of our assets, strengthening our balance sheet, and creating the best conditions for these franchises‚Äô long term growth and success. With its dedicated and autonomous leadership team, it will focus on transforming these three brands into unique ecosystems.

‚ÄúWe are committed to building a sharper, more focused organization-one where talented teams will take our brands to the next level, accelerate the growth of emerging franchises, and lead innovation in next generation technologies and services, all with the goal of delivering enriching, memorable games that exceed players' expectations, and create superior value for our shareholders and other stakeholders.‚Äù

So, what does the deal mean in reality? This new subsidiary includes the teams developing the Rainbow Six, Assassin‚Äôs Creed, and Far Cry franchises based in Montr√©al, Quebec, Sherbrooke, Saguenay, Barcelona, and Sofia, as well as Ubisoft‚Äôs back-catalog and any new games currently under development or to be developed. So, it sounds like existing projects are safe, and there is no word yet on more layoffs.

The transaction is expected to complete by the end of 2025.

Tencent to retain a 25 percent share of the new subsidiary.

Ubisoft has announced the establishment of a dedicated subsidiary based on its Assassin‚Äôs Creed, Far Cry, and Tom Clancy‚Äôs Rainbow Six brands, spearheaded by an investment of ‚Ç¨1.16 billion from Chinese conglomerate Tencent, who will retain a 25 percent minority stake in the subsidiary.

The new subsidiary will focus on ‚Äúbuilding game ecosystems designed to become truly evergreen and multiplatform,‚Äù and drive further increaess in quality of narrative solo experience, expand multiplayer offerings with increased frequency of content releases, introduce free-to-play touchpoints, and integrate more social features.

The agreement with Tencent follows Ubisoft exploring and assessing different strategic options as announced earlier in 2025. After careful consideration of several expressions of interested from various parties, Ubisoft determined this transaction to be the bst value for its assets and approved the proposition today.

In parallel to the creation of this new subsidiary, Ubisoft will focus on ‚Äúnurturing the devleopment of iconic franchises‚Äù such as Tom Clancy‚Äôs Ghost Recon and The Division, accelerating the growth of top performing titles and leveraging disruptive technologies on selected new intellectual properties, while continuing to deliver ‚Äústate-of-the-art production‚Äù game engines and online services.

‚ÄúToday Ubisoft is opening a new chapter in its history,‚Äù said Ubisoft co-founder and CEO Yves Guillemot in a press release. ‚ÄúAs we accelerate the company‚Äôs transformation, this is a foundational step in changing Ubisoft‚Äôs operating model that will enable us to be both agile and ambitious. We are focused on building strong game ecosystems designed to become evergreen, growing high-performing brands and creating new IPs powered by cutting-edge and emerging technologies.

‚ÄúWith the creation of a dedicated subsidiary that will spearhead development for three of our largest franchises and the onboarding of Tencent as a minority investor, we are crystalizing the value of our assets, strengthening our balance sheet, and creating the best conditions for these franchises‚Äô long-term growth and success. With its dedicated and autonomous leadership team, it will focus on transforming these three brands into unique ecosystems.‚Äù

Guillemot concluded, ‚ÄúWe are committed to building a sharper, more focused organization-one where talented teams will take our brands to the next level, accelerate the growth of emerging franchises, and lead innovation in next-generation technologies and services, all with the goal of delivering enriching, memorable games that exceed players‚Äô expectations, and create superior value for our shareholders and other stakeholders.‚Äù

Tencent president Martin Lau added, ‚ÄúWe are excited to extend our longstanding partnership with Ubisoft through this investment, which reflects our continued confidence in Ubisoft‚Äôs creative vision and exceptional talent to drive sustained success in the industry. We see the immense potential for these franchises to evolve into long-term evergreen game platforms and create engaging new experiences for gamers.‚Äù

Here is the full breakdown of the new subsidiary and deal with Tencent:

Relationship between the new subsidiary and Ubisoft Entertainment

  • The new subsidiary would include the teams developing the Tom Clancy‚Äôs Rainbow Six, Assassin‚Äôs Creed, and Far Cry franchises based in Montr√©al, Quebec, Sherbrooke, Saguenay, Barcelona, and Sofia as well as the back-catalog and any new games currently under development or to be developed.
  • The new subsidiary would be granted by Ubisoft a worldwide, exclusive, irrevocable, perpetual license in respect of the intellectual property and similar proprietary rights owned or licensable by Ubisoft in relation to Tom Clancy‚Äôs Rainbow Six, Assassin‚Äôs Creed, and Far Cry in exchange for a royalty.

Main terms of the binding agreement with Tencent

  • Tencent would invest in the new subsidiary which is headquartered in France and 100% owned by Ubisoft immediately prior to the transaction. Specifically, at closing of the transaction, Tencent would invest a total amount of EUR1.16bn for an approximate 25% economic interest in the New subsidiary, that will be used to strengthen Ubisoft‚Äôs balance sheet by significantly reducing its consolidated net debt position, accelerate the Group‚Äôs transformation, and sustain growth of selected franchises. After closing of the transaction, the new subsidiary would remain exclusively controlled and consolidated by Ubisoft.
  • Conditions precedent to the transaction:
    • Issuance of a fairness opinion from Finexsi acting as independent expert.
    • Completion of the carve-out to create the new subsidiary.
    • Obtention of the necessary regulatory clearances
    • Ubisoft can unilaterally waive the issuance of the fairness opinion as a condition precedent.
  • Completion of the transaction is expected before the end of 2025.
  • The new subsidiary would have a dedicated leadership team, supervised by a Board of Directors, focused on enhancing creative vision and streamlining operations, with the authority to make swift, high-impact decisions across development, marketing, and distribution, to ensure these brands continue to evolve, attract new audiences, and deliver groundbreaking gaming experiences for years to come.
  • Tencent would benefit from customary minority protection rights as well as certain consent rights on the disposals of the important new subsidiary assets.
  • Other provisions in relation to Tencent‚Äôs shareholding in the New subsidiary notably include:
  • A 5-year lock-up undertaking on New subsidiary shares held by Tencent, unless Ubisoft no longer owns a majority of New subsidiary voting rights and share capital.
  • Ubisoft may not cease to hold a majority of New subsidiary voting rights and share capital for a 2-year period.
  • Customary share transfer provisions, including, a right of first refusal to the benefit of Ubisoft, a right of first offer to the benefit of Tencent, tag-along right to the benefit of Tencent, and drag-along right to the benefit of Ubisoft (subject to certain conditions).
  • Call option to the benefit of Ubisoft and put option to the benefit of Tencent in the event of certain change of control of Ubisoft approved by its Board of Directors‚ÄîExercise price will be the higher of (i) the fair market value of New subsidiary shares and (ii) the same EBIT multiple as that in the change of control transaction of Ubisoft; it being specified that for the call option there will be a specific minimum price protection during the first four years following closing of the transaction with Tencent.

item.title: Ubisoft launches new business for Assassin's Creed and other big IPs, with ‚Ç¨1.16bn Tencent investment
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/ubisoft-launches-new-business-for-assassins-creed-and-other-big-ips-with-116bn-tencent-investment

Calls move a "new chapter" for the company.

Ubisoft has launched a new subsidiary dedicated to its big three IPs - Assassin's Creed, Rainbow Six, and Far Cry - in a move CEO Yves Guillemot calls a "new chapter" for the company. Chinese conglomerated Tencent will hold a minority stake in the new entity, having invested ‚Ç¨1.16bn.

Ubisoft's announcement follows several recent reports such a move was being considered behind the scenes. Earlier this month, Bloomberg claimed Ubisoft was mulling over the launch of a fresh business unit part-owned by outside companies, noting such a tactic could potentially result in the new entity being valued higher than Ubisoft itself following years of falling share prices and a string of disappointing game launches.

In today's official announcement, Ubisoft valued its new subsidiary at around ‚Ç¨4bn. This, it wrote, "highlights the strong value of [its] IPs, significantly reinforces its balance sheet, and enables the company to continue its efforts to become a more agile organisation, unleash the full creative potential of its teams and better align its resources with the constantly evolving expectations of players."

It also confirmed the business unit will be the new home of all Assassin's Creed, Rainbow Six, and Far cry development teams based in Montr√©al, Quebec, Sherbrooke, Saguenay, Barcelona, and Sofia. Additionally, the subsidiary will control each series' "back-catalog and any new games currently under development or to be developed."

"Today Ubisoft is opening a new chapter in its history," Ubisoft CEO Yves Guillemot wrote in a statement accompanying the announcement. "As we accelerate the company's transformation, this is a foundational step in changing Ubisoft's operating model that will enable us to be both agile and ambitious. We are focused on building strong game ecosystems designed to become evergreen, growing high-performing brands and creating new IPs powered by cutting-edge and emerging technologies."

As to what the new subsidiary will actually do, Guillemot says it'll focus on "transforming [Assassin's Creed, Rainbow Six, and Far Cry] into unique ecosystems". The announcement takes this a little further, claiming the "greater investment and boosted creative capacities [will] drive further increases in quality of narrative solo experiences, expand multiplayer offerings with increased frequency of content release, introduce free-to-play touchpoints, and integrate more social features."

Away from the new subsidiary and its three big name brands, Ubisoft says it'll concentrate on "nurturing the development of iconic franchises including Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon and The Division, accelerating the growth of top performing titles and leveraging disruptive technologies on selected new IPs, while continuing to deliver state-of-the-art production game engines and online services." More details are set to be shared at a later day.

This seismic shake-up of Ubisoft's structure follows a tumultuous few years for the publisher - which earlier this year confirmed it was undertaking a strategic review to help it right-size the business, amid tumbling share prices and a number of high-profile flops, including last year's Star Wars Outlaws. Ubisoft's failings have also significantly impacted staff - a string of job cuts and studio closures in recent times have seen its employee numbers shrink from over 20,279 people in 2022, to 18,666 in September 2024, with more redundancies having been made since then.

It remains to be seen whether Ubisoft's newly announced subsidiary can help change its fortunes, but the publisher has recently celebrated the launch of Assassin's Creed Shadows after numerous delays. Earlier this month it said Shadows had topped over two million players, "surpassing the launches of [Assassin's Creed] Origins and Odyssey".

item.title: Everything Announced at the AdeptiCon 2025 Preview Event
item.content:encoded:

Games Workshop recently held its AdeptiCon 2025 Preview event. During this event, the UK-based tabletop studio announced new products coming Warhammer 40,000, Warhammer Age of Sigmar, and Warhammer The Old World. Here is everything they announced.

The AdeptiCon 2025 Preview Event Announcements

In an official Warhammer-Community post, Games Workshop assembled everything announced during the AdeptiCon 2025 preview event. Those announcements covered both major tentpole franchises and various spin-offs.

For fans of the grimdark sci-fi future of Warhammer 40,000, the first big announcement centered on the space viking chapter of the Space Marines. Yes, the Space Wolves are getting new miniatures, a dedicated army box, and their own codex. These new miniatures include new Wolf Guard units and the Blood Claws.

For those that have rejected Imperium dogma, the preview included a new look at several Chaos Space Marine chapters. Like the Emperor's Children, the World Eaters, Death Guard, and Thousand Sons are getting their own dedicated codices. More blood for the Blood God.

On the gameplay side of things, the AdeptiCon 2025 Preview event highlighted a new Chapter Approved Mission Deck. This deck will change Matched Play by introducing three new ways to play: Incursion (1000 points), Strike Force (2,000 points) and the new Asymmetrical War mode. As the name implies, Asymmetrical War features uneven deployment zones and differing primary objectives.

Lastly, a new Warhammer 40,000 Kill Team box has been announced. The Typhon box ramps up the battle on Volkus, where the Adeptus Mechanicus must fend off a swarm of Tyranids. Yes, playable Tyranids are coming to Kill Team. The box even includes Tyranid-themed terrain.

In the land of the Mortal Realms, the AdeptiCon 2025 Preview event confirmed a new Warhammer Age of Sigmar Spearhead set. The set, Spearhead: Sand and Bone, brings the smaller, more streamlined Spearhead rules to the dark lands of Dolorum and the chilling deserts of Ossia. The set includes new twists, Battle Tactics, Objectives, rules for four new Spearhead armies, and terrain fitting a Realm of Death.

Those new Spearhead armies are the Cities of Sigmar's Fusil-Platoon, the Serephon Sunblood Prowlers, the Ossiarch Bonereapers Mortisan Elite, and the Ogor Mawtribes Scrapglutt.

Last but not least, the AdeptiCon 2025 preview event spotlighted Warhammer The Old World. First is the introduction of the Grand Cathay army for the forces of Order. This East Asia-coded army will be getting an arcane journal and battalion box with 50 miniatures. Those miniatures will include 30 Jade Warriors, 10 Jade Lancers, two different artillery units, and the battalion's leader: A Shugengan Lord astride their Great Spirit Longma mount.

The preview extends into the forests of the old world. On the side of chaos are the forest-dwelling, corruption-spreading Beastmen Brayherds. They will be receiving an arcane journal and battlion box of their own. Their units include ferocious shamans, chieftains, Tuskgor Chariots. Challenging them on the side of Order are the Wood Elf Realms wit their own battalion box respectively.

This preview is but a glimpse of announcements and developments coming to Games Workshop's franchises in the future. Release dates and price points for these announced products are all pending.

item.title: Nintendo is paving the way for the Switch 2
item.content:encoded:
https://www.theverge.com/nintendo/637597/nintendo-virtual-game-cards-switch-2

The biggest news at Nintendo‚Äôs March Direct showcase was a software update. Mixed in amongst a trailer for Metroid Prime 4: Beyond and the surprise reveal of a mobile news app, the company also announced what it calls ‚Äúvirtual game cards.‚Äù They‚Äôre billed as a lending system that makes it relatively straightforward to share digital games between devices. But really, they‚Äôre a tool that could make the transition to the Switch 2 later this year much easier.

As Nintendo explains it, these virtual cards work a lot like physical cartridges. You can ‚Äúeject‚Äù a game from one device and then load it onto another, so long as the second Switch is tied to your account or a member of your family plan. Digital games ‚Äúcan also be lent to a Nintendo Account family group member‚Äôs system via local wireless connection,‚Äù and they‚Äôll be able to play the game for two weeks before it‚Äôs automatically returned to you.

It‚Äôs an extremely Nintendo feature, in that it‚Äôs a playful attempt at bringing traditional physical game features into the digital realm, and that it also has some caveats, like the limited two week period, which is nowhere near enough time to make a dent in Tears of the Kingdom. Still, it seems to be a step up from the way sharing currently works, where a secondary Switch can only play games if it‚Äôs connected to the internet to verify things, rendering it largely useless while traveling. Nintendo specifies in the fine print that ‚Äúonce a virtual game card is loaded to a system, not only can you play it without an internet connection, but other user accounts on the system can play, too.‚Äù

More interesting than the feature itself is the timing. It‚Äôll be available as part of a system update for the Switch at some point in April. Also happening in April? The big Nintendo Direct where the company will reveal actual details of the Switch 2, presumably including the price, release date, and line-up of launch games. Expectations are it won‚Äôt be much longer after that before the Switch 2 finally launches.

Sorting out the sharing features is good news for current Switch owners. But because it‚Äôs happening at the end of that console‚Äôs lifecycle, it‚Äôs pretty clear Nintendo means for this to be a hopefully painless way of moving to the Switch 2. The next console will be backward compatible with original Switch games, and that library is incredibly important. Not only is it huge, but it‚Äôs filled with some of Nintendo‚Äôs most successful games ever, like Breath of the Wild, Animal Crossing: New Horizons, Mario Kart 8 Deluxe, and Super Mario Odyssey.

And it‚Äôs a library that keeps growing: there are still major Switch 1 games in the works for this year, like Metroid and Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A, while the just-announced Tomodachi Life: Living the Dream doesn‚Äôt even launch until 2026. In the press release announcing the virtual game cards, Nintendo made sure to note that they ‚Äúwill also work with Nintendo Switch 2 systems at launch.‚Äù

Nintendo has always had a complicated relationship with the internet and user accounts (see: Friend Codes). But the new virtual card system at least makes it clear that the company sees the importance of creating a more unified system for users to play things across devices. Because whenever the Switch 2 does launch later this year, there‚Äôs going to be a whole lot more people with multiple consoles in their homes.

item.title: Ubisoft Employees Worried About Layoffs After Tencent Deal
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/ubisoft-employees-worried-about-layoffs-after-tencent-deal/

On Thursday afternoon, Ubisoft announced that it was forming a new subsidiary company with Tencent that will include the company‚Äôs three biggest franchises along with a number of studios. This has led to a number of employees within Ubisoft to become worried about mass layoffs happening in the coming months either before or after the deal with Tencent is completed.

Not long after the deal was announced, multiple current Ubisoft employees reached out to express feelings of uneasiness and concern about the future of the company. Specifically, those not working on Assassin‚Äôs Creed, Far Cry, and Rainbow Six.

In an internal email acquired by Insider Gaming, Ubisoft‚Äôs Marie-Sophie de Waubert said that she understands that there is uncertainty and questions surrounding what‚Äôs going to happen. She also tried to calm any worries about those not working on the three franchises.

‚ÄúI also want to be clear: if you‚Äôre not currently working on these brands, it doesn‚Äôt mean your work matters any less,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThis agreement will benefit all of Ubisoft, giving us the means to spark more innovation and creativity across the board. This marks the beginning of a new chapter, and you play a vital role in shaping it.‚Äù

Despite the messaging, however, some aren‚Äôt buying it.

‚ÄúWe feel [expletive] if we‚Äôre not on the big three,‚Äù one current Ubisoft employee said under the condition of anonymity. ‚ÄúThey can say these things in an email, but when it comes down to it, we feel like we know where priorities are.‚Äù

Said another employee currently working on an unannounced project, ‚ÄúI want to think our team is okay right now, but we don‚Äôt know. You‚Äôd think they‚Äôd have at least some sort of clarity for us before publicly announcing the deal.‚Äù

The other messages received all relayed similar sentiments. There is some excitement and hope that a turnaround is coming for the company, but until questions about their status are answered, those in various areas of the company don‚Äôt want to get happy.

‚ÄúWe just want to know what‚Äôs going on,‚Äù one source said. ‚ÄúThey promised transparency and regular communication with us, but we‚Äôll see if that actually happens.‚Äù

Insider Gaming has reached out to Ubisoft regarding what the deal with Tencent means for its employees and the possibility of layoffs. Should a response be received, it will be added to the article.

The product has evolved into something akin to Slack, but for personal use. It's used by artist communities, game developers, open source projects, influencers, and more to manage communities and coordinate work. In some cases, people simply use it as an extremely robust group messaging tool for groups of friends without any games or projects involved.

Limited ads to tackle limited revenue

For years, Discord proudly touted a "no ads" policy, but that dam has broken in some small ways in recent months. Discord began offering game publishers opportunities to create special "quests" that appear in the Discord interface, wherein players can earn in-game rewards for doing specific tasks, like streaming a game to friends. A new format, called video quests, is planned for this summer, too.

The new ad products are meant to drum up Discord's revenue potential in the lead-up to an IPO; the platform already offered premium subscriptions for access to more advanced features and a marketplace for cosmetics to jazz up profiles.

So far, the ad products are, by and large, much less intrusive than ads in many other social networks and seem to be oriented around providing some user value. However, an IPO could lead to shareholders demanding more from the company in pursuit of revenue.

item.title: Neil Druckmann Doesn't Worry About TLOU Spoilers After They Previously "Blew Up In My Face"
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/neil-druckmann-doesnt-worry-about-tlou-spoilers-after-they-previously-blew-up-in-my-face/1100-6530437/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

When The Last of Us Part II debuted in 2020, it did so after a few major plot points were spoiled online well in advance. Now, with the show set to adapt that story when The Last of Us Season 2 premieres on HBO in a few weeks, there's a risk a whole new audience will have their experience altered by the prevalence of spoilers online. But for showrunners Craig Mazin and Neil Druckmann, the latter of whom is now living through this predicament for a second time, spoilers aren't a huge concern.

"I feel like the best way I could respect the audience is by not thinking about them too much when I'm working on whatever I'm writing. That way I could just make the best decision with as little outside influence as possible, and make the best internal decisions for the characters, for the story, for the medium," Druckmann told GameSpot. "And you know, when it comes to like, what are we going to spoil or not spoil? You know, I fought tooth-and-nail when we made the game, and that all blew up in my face at the end, when we had those leaks that happened like months before the game came out. So I've learned to not put so much stock in that. But also, now I have a creative partner, HBO. I kind of follow their lead here as far as spoilers and what we should show and not show and just, you know, again, approach it as if we're doing it for the first time, assuming the audience doesn't know anything. They're not Googling what happened in the game or not."

Even with spoilers floating around for those who can't resist looking for them, the second season, like the first season, changes some details in order to ensure the team is "making the best choices for this moment in time," as a TV audience has different needs than a video game player.

"But also, again, my approach with the show is, I assume you know nothing," he continued. "I assume you haven't played the game. I guess there's some assumption you've watched the first season, but even that, we're not 100% sure, so HBO created this beautiful recap of Season 1."

I asked the pair if the production team created any content meant as spoiler disinformation, like when creators for Lost or Game of Thrones would film scenes they had no plans to use just to fill the spoiler forums with disorienting noise--a practice that horrifies Mazin.

"The thing is, it's really hard to make the show. We use every second of every day to make the stuff we want to make," he said. "The thought of spending time shooting stuff we don't want to make is sort of a horrifying prospect to me. And I think Neil's right. The thing about spoiler stuff is it's kind of overrated; the impact that it has is overrated. And you can look at that just empirically with The Last of Us Part II, which had the leaks. There was all this spoiler outrage, and then the games sold gazillions of copies and won every award you can win, and it was beautiful. It didn't matter the spoiler. Like, I always use the example of Titanic, although, honestly, I could use Chernobyl, too. 'Hey, here's a spoiler. It blew up, right?' [The] Titanic sinks, and we all still went to the theater to watch it because we don't care about that. We care about the relationships."

The Last of Us Season 2 premieres on HBO and Max beginning on April 13 and will run for seven episodes on a weekly release schedule. The season won't cover all of The Last of Us Part II's story, and a third season is planned, though not yet officially announced.

item.title: Pentiment director explains how going all-in on fonts helped elevate the medieval Detective RPG.
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamedeveloper.com/design/pentiment-director-explains-how-going-all-in-on-fonts-helped-elevate-the-medieval-detective-rpg-

Obsidian Entertainment's Pentiment was one of the developer's most unorthodox role-playing games, a 2D detective story in an illustrated book set in 16th-century Bavaria. While Pentiment didn't have the massive scope of the dev's other titles like Fallout: New Vegas or the most recent Avowed, the game's director did have one particular vision for the game's storytelling that required a significant amount of convincing to get the team on board‚Äîand that was with how the fonts would look in-game.

During GDC 2025, game director Joshua Sawyer (previously helming Fallout: New Vegas and Pillars of Eternity) spoke about his work conceptualizing and building Pentiment's approach to text-based storytelling and how the game's fonts needed more than static characters in speech bubbles to authentically depict an evolving game world with different cultures via a "typographic voice."

Rats, horse testicles, and fonts‚ÄîOR: How to go the extra mile with your game

At Sawyer's panel, titled "Justifying Absurd Expenditures on Fonts and Other Silly Features," he broke down some common struggles developers tend to fall into when trying to deliver a product. In many cases, developers tend to provide a game that is seen as a "minimum viable product," especially at first. which is a game with baseline features and nothing particularly noteworthy. Another approach is to elevate the concept go for the "maximum viable product."

Related:Why your next game needs a babygirl

Some examples he included were A Plague Tale's dynamic, fully animated rat swarms, which appear like a living mass to players. In another example, Sawyer brought up Red Dead Redemption 2's infamous horse testicles, which shrink when riding in cold climates. As Sawyer put it, adding these features‚Äîwhich aren't always vital for a game‚Äîdo a lot to elevate the experience into something more.

"What about the maximum viable product? It's way more than what's needed, you got every bell and whistle‚Äîyou're inventing bells and whistles, and you're trying to elevate the experience through a type of unique maximalism that hasn't been seen [in a game]," said Sawyer.

Following the above, Sawyer explained his vision for Pentiment, a 16th-century European detective game where players must read and analyze intent and meaning from character interactions to make critical choices. Inspired by games like 80 Days and Night in the Woods, Pentiment's unique approach to storytelling highlights its dynamic text presentation, featuring animated medieval-era typography that's unique for each interaction and NPC. This gives Pentiment a feeling that you're looking into a living medieval-era painting or illustrated tome that's being created as you go‚Äîwhich Sawyer stated was to depict the "physicality of writing in books."

Related:UC Santa Cruz professor roleplays gig economy, publisher negotiation, and layoffs with game design students

Depending on your choices and the protagonist Andreas's growth, the game's approach to text will evolve and shift over the course of the game. As the game director described it, being passionate about a feature is the first step of getting your concept off the ground, but the following steps include getting your team on board with the idea and then bringing it to life in a compelling way‚Äîwhich present unique challenges all their own.

"One of many problems is that there were [letter] character set issues, so these might have supported the languages they originally came from," said Sawyer. "For example, many of the [characters] came from German or Swiss sources; while they might have been clear, they didn't have the characters that might be needed in Polish or Spanish or French or anything else. So that was tricky. Also, if they looked authentic [to the era], they were often quite difficult to read. Yes, we wanted them to look authentic, but the difficult-to-read part is not good for a game full of text."

What's in a font?

Related:Achieving 'creative sobriety' in game design

Sawyer described Pentiment as "not a small game, but not an 'indie' game"‚Äîgiven that it had support from Microsoft Game Studios. With over three years in development and a team of 13 by the end of production, it was a modestly sized game, but Sawyer's ideas for using dynamic typography for its storytelling presented a wrinkle that took time to work out.

What sets Pentiment apart from other reading-dense RPGs like Disco Elysium or Pillars of the Earth is how it makes the act of reading‚Äîand viewing the text‚Äîa part of the experience. You essentially become a medieval-era detective. This was a part of the core vision of Pentiment, in that 16th century Bavaria was a melting pot of different cultures and social classes, and protagonist Andreas must be able to navigate a diverse society with unique characters who have different philosophies and worldviews, all reflected in the font-style.

To build out the whole suite of custom typography, the developers contacted Lettermatic founder Riley Cran. Working with Cran's company, they designed the game's six custom fonts‚ÄîPeasant, Cursive, Humanist, Printed, Textura, and Thread Puller. Creating each font‚Äîaiming for authenticity rather than total accuracy‚Äî allowed the developers greater control over the text, at the cost of being time-consuming. Sawyer recommended that devs try to create their fonts to own it, but only if they have the resources and means to do so.

"The control you have with the fonts is unparalleled, it's fantastic," he said. "You can get exactly what you need; you can get support for any localization you want, and it's your font. You don't have to worry about ongoing licensing issues and all that sort of nonsense. We eventually released our fonts for basically free to the public, and they use it for making shit posts and memes, which is the highest point of it."

Another vital resource that Obsidian Entertainment relied on was the accessibility teams at Microsoft, who helped hone the visual presentation of the text for readers of all kinds and text related to specific cultures. Sawyer cited some instances where the game touched on specific topics, and Microsoft sensitivity readers offered feedback to help refine it further.

One method that Sawyer suggested to elevate the look of the text and give it a dynamic feel was the stroke-by-stroke illustration of letters in real-time, which he noted wasn't exactly met with enthusiasm from the team. "So when I brought up stroke-by-stroke rendering to the team, it wasn't that people hated the idea, but there was skepticism about it," said Sawyer. Eventually, the engineering team‚Äîopting out of his initial pitch of using different alpha channels to similar motion‚Äîused his concept and built it with Adobe Illustrator, applying gradients and animation to recreate real-time illustrative pen strokes on parchment.

Sell your vision

Sawyer concluded the talk by giving attendees tips on how to best present their concepts to their teams. For Pentiment, the dynamic text and fonts showcased a level of authenticity for the game's setting and concept of playing within a living book‚Äîsomething that Sawyer admitted took effort to get right.

"It is not enough for you alone to believe in this mission‚Äîthe team does have to believe in this vision as well," said Sawyer. "The vision also has to include a plan, which will make people feel somewhat more confident in the idea that you are giving them. If you succeed with the core features, people will be more confident and happier about the idea of doing other things related to it."

The decision to go the extra mile was worth it as Pentiment is widely regarded as one of Obsidian Entertainment's best games. All it took to help the game reach its success and elevate its concept was coming up with an idea that seemed far-fetched, but ultimately worth the effort.

Contributor

Alessandro Fillari is a writer/editor who has covered the games, tech, and entertainment industries for more than 12 years. He is based in the San Francisco Bay Area.

item.title: Ubisoft Is Getting $1.25 Billion From Tencent To Spin-Off Assassin's Creed, Far Cry, And Rainbow Six Siege
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/ubisoft-tencent-assassins-creed-far-cry-rainbow-six-1851772796

Ubsioft will spin off its most successful game franchises, including Assassin‚Äôs Creed, Far Cry, and Rainbow Six Siege, into a separate subsidiary thanks to a $1.25 billion investment from Chinese conglomerate Tencent. The massive deal allows the founding Guillemot family to remain in control of the publisher despite its recent struggles and cratering share price.

Suggested Reading

The details of the agreement are complex and it‚Äôs not immediately clear how it will all hash out in practice. The new entity doesn‚Äôt have a name yet but will have its own board of supervisors and include Ubisoft studios Montreal, Quebec, Sherbrooke, Saguenay, Barcelona, and Sofia. Those teams will be in charge of the Assassin‚Äôs Creed, Far Cry, and Rainbow Six Siege franchises moving forward, as well as their back catalogs. But all of it will still report up to Ubisoft proper and its current CEO, Yves Guillemot.

‚ÄúWith the creation of a dedicated subsidiary that will spearhead development for three of our largest franchises and the onboarding of Tencent as a minority investor, we are crystalizing the value of our assets, strengthening our balance sheet, and creating the best conditions for these franchises‚Äô long-term growth and success,‚Äù Guillemot said in a press release on Thursday. ‚ÄúWith its dedicated and autonomous leadership team, it will focus on transforming these three brands into unique ecosystems.‚Äù

On a call with investors following the announcement, however, the company‚Äôs leadership clarified that Ubisoft 2, or whatever it ends up being called, will still report up to Guillemot. ‚ÄúThere will be a dedicated management under the supervision of a board that will be controlled by Ubisoft,‚Äù CFO Frederick Duguet told investors. ‚ÄúSo Ubisoft will continue controlling and consolidating this entity.‚Äù

The major deal comes after months of speculation about a possible sale of the French publisher following a year of poor sales for some of its biggest recent blockbusters, including Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora and Star Wars Outlaws, as well as delays and cancellations of other big releases, including free-to-play shooter The Division Heartland. Those rumors included a shareholder report that Ubisoft was even exploring a sale of some of its franchises to Microsoft and others. Under the new structure, series like The Division, Ghost Recon, The Crew, Prince of Persia, and Rayman will remain under the broader Ubisoft umbrella.

Ubisoft is a sprawling organization with studios and employees spread out all over the world. The complex web facilitates a co-development process that the company uses to ship massive games in shorter time periods. But that also means that there‚Äôs no clean delineation between who works on what. While The Montreal and Quebec studios lead development on the Assassin‚Äôs Creed franchise, many employees within those offices still work on other franchises as needed.

Asked by investors how many of Ubisoft‚Äôs over 17,000 employees would be moving to the new group, the company said it was still too early to tell. That sentiment was echoed in an email sent to staff today from Ubisoft head of studios Marie-Sophie de Waubert. This brings some uncertainty and questions,‚Äù she wrote in an email obtained by Insider Gaming. ‚ÄúRight now, we may not have all the detailed answers, but we are committed to communicating with you transparently and regularly.‚Äù

Two key provisions of the new agreement are that Tencent cannot sell its 25 percent equity stake for at least five years and Ubisoft ‚Äúmay not cease to hold a majority of New subsidiary voting rights and share capital for a 2-year period.‚Äù In the near term at least, the $1.25 billion deal sounds more like a financial instrument than anything else, and one that provides Ubisoft‚Äôs current ownership with more time to try to improve the company‚Äôs financial outlook. Prior to Assassin‚Äôs Creed Shadow‚Äôs launch, many asked if it would be enough to save the company from being broken up and sold for parts. For now at least, it seems like it won‚Äôt need to.

Cult-classic rhythm strategy bundle Patapon 1+2 Replay is bringing two beloved PSP games to PC, Nintendo Switch, and PlayStation 5 (PS5) July 11.

The two-pack remaster was revealed during today‚Äôs March 2025 Nintendo Direct alongside gameplay and its summer launch plan. It‚Äôs a move that finally allows two hidden-gem PlayStation games from the mid-2000s to stomp onto non-PlayStation platforms for the first time while updating them for PS5 players, too.

‚ÄúHaving lived in the desolate frontier for years, the Patapon tribe was driven from their home by the Zigoton army,‚Äù an official description from new publisher Bandai Namco said.

‚ÄúThis drove them to become fierce warrior spirits that can only be commanded by the beat of the war drum, played by the Mighty One (the player). Their wait has finally come to an end as the drums of war are heard once again by the Almighty‚Äôs return to guide the Patapon tribe through their adventures to fight against challenging enemies and return them to their homeland.‚Äù

Patapon 1+2 Replay seems to come with a few upgrades not seen in the 2017 PS4 remasters. Bandai Namco specifically lists upgraded graphics as one of the more noticeable additions, though returning Almighty will also notice added Easy, Normal, and Hard difficulty modes, as well as timing adjustment and constant command display options. While Patapon 1+2 Replay aims to bring the classic 2007 and 2008 titles to players better than ever, there‚Äôs no sign of the PSP‚Äôs 2011 title, Patapon 3.

Patapon may not be one of PlayStation‚Äôs more recognizable franchises, but it‚Äôs still a name that has been associated with the brand for nearly 20 years. It‚Äôs unclear why or how it‚Äôs leaping other platforms now or if the series will continue to blossom with any new entries in the future. There‚Äôs also been no mention of a potential Xbox version, so it‚Äôs best to expect Patapon 1+2 Replay on PC, Switch, and PS5 to be where things end for now.

It's got both serious and wacky golf.

Golfers will have good reason to get back on the green this year. Everybody's Golf Hot Shots adds another entry to the long-running golf series for PlayStation 5, Nintendo Switch, and PC via Steam later this year.

This particular franchise has historically gone by two names. While called Everybody's Golf in many regions, the series was Hot Shots Golf in North America for a while, until 2017's Everybody's Golf reunited the franchise name. This latest entry, Everybody's Golf Hot Shots, looks to mark as much by combining the two names into one unified, new entry.

There's an interesting twist in the details, though. Digimon Survive studio HYDE is making this, under the Bandai Namco umbrella, in a partnership with Sony Interactive Entertainment. Traditionally, this has been a Sony-published series, and developer Clap Hanz was working on the series. Clap Haz released its own self-titled game, Clap Hanz Golf, back in 2021.

Still, it looks like you can expect the usual blend of classic golf and some of the wackier options. Characters have their expressive celebrations, and several game modes offer strange, surprising mix-ups to your usual round of golf.

There will also be local couch co-op and online multiplayer, which is good news for those who, like me, grew up passing a controller around playing Hot Shots Golf. The announcement debuted during today's Nintendo Switch Direct, and I could see Everybody's Golf Hot Shots working pretty well as a couch co-op Switch game.

No date's been set yet, but Everybody's Golf Hot Shots will be heading to PS5, Switch, and PC sometime this year.

In the meantime, head over to our recap of today's Nintendo Direct for March 2025 if you're looking for other announcements.   • Switch
  • Switch 2

Easily manage your purchased digital games

Nintendo has announced the Virtual Game Cards digital games management system for Switch and Switch 2. It is a new system that aims to simplify digital game management and enable players to lend or borrow games between multiple Nintendo Account family group members. It will launch for Switch in late April as a system software update, and will be available on Switch 2 at launch.

Here are the details:

Virtual Game Cards Make Digital Games Even Easier to Use

The virtual game card feature for Nintendo Switch* and Nintendo Switch 2 systems adds some of the flexibility of physical game cards to your digital game library!

If you have two systems, you can digitally eject and load games from one system to another‚Äîand you can even lend games to members of your Nintendo Account family group.

‚ÄîOpen the HOME Menu and select Virtual Game Cards.

‚ÄîView your digital game library. (Virtual game cards may not be available for demos and some Nintendo Switch Online member exclusive games.)

‚ÄîSelect the game you want to load‚Äîand start playing as soon as the game data is downloaded!

Move Your Games Between Systems

If you have two different systems linked to the same Nintendo Account**, you can choose which system to play it on‚Äîjust like with a physical game card. Simply eject the virtual game card from one system and load it onto the other.

Once a virtual game card is loaded to a system***, not only can you play it without an internet connection, but other user accounts on the system can play, too.

You can also manage and load virtual game cards via your Nintendo Account on the Nintendo website.

Lend Games to Members of Your Nintendo Account Family Group

You can also lend out virtual game cards to your Nintendo Account family group members. Just connect to your family group member‚Äôs system via local wireless when you want to lend a game. Both systems must also be connected to the internet.

You can lend one game per account for 14 days (unless the borrower returns it earlier).

After the game is returned the borrower will still have their save data, so they‚Äôll be able to start where they left off if they borrow again or purchase the game.

Both local wireless and internet communication are required for lending software. Please note that some games, such as games available only as part of a Nintendo Switch Online membership, cannot be lent out.

*Available on Nintendo Switch, Nintendo Switch Lite, and Nintendo Switch ‚Äì OLED Model systems in late April 2025. A system update is required to use this feature on Nintendo Switch systems.

**Compatible systems must be linked to a Nintendo Account to use virtual game cards. Nintendo Switch 2 exclusive games and Nintendo Switch 2 Edition games can only be loaded on a Nintendo Switch 2 system. To move virtual game cards between two systems, you must pair the systems via local wireless and an internet connection, but only when pairing the systems for the first time. Up to two systems total can be linked per Nintendo Account.

*** An internet connection is required the first time you start a game that you have loaded to your system. An internet connection is also required each time a loaded title is ejected.

Hand-drawn side-scrolling platformer The Eternal Life of Goldman will launch for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, Switch, and PC via Steam this holiday, publisher THQ Nordic and developer Weappy announced.

Here is an overview of the game, via THQ Nordic:

About

In this breathtaking platformer adventure, explore a vast hand-drawn Archipelago, inspired by ancient fables and depicted in classic frame-by-frame animation, and defeat a mysterious Deity.

A Tale With Hidden Depths

The Eternal Life of Goldman is a vibrant yet dark adventure that weaves together legends, fairy tales and myths. It takes the genre at an unusual angle and offers something unexpected at every turn.

You arrive at the Archipelago on a strange mission: to kill the Deity, a mystical creature that everyone talks about, but no one has seen. To find the Deity, you will have to delve deep into the many secrets these islands keep. You will discover a place marked by tragedy, and filled with eccentric characters and remarkable contrasts.

Upgrade your cane with new parts and unlock new abilities, to explore the hidden corners of the Archipelago and face incredible creatures.

Hand Crafted to the Smallest Detail

The Eternal Life of Goldman is the result of years of work by people who love and appreciate the same cartoons, comics and games that you do. We wanted to make an uncompromising 2D game of amazing beauty, so we went back to the genre‚Äôs roots and took the most difficult path possible ‚Äì meticulously drawn, colored and animated by hand using classic frame-by-frame techniques. We didn‚Äôt cut any corners, and the results are worth it. In The Eternal Life of Goldman, no two rooms or landscapes are alike. Every place, every object, every character, every visual effect ‚Äî everything is carefully planned and executed to the finest detail.

Remember how, when you were a child, you first saw your first 16-bit platformer and couldn‚Äôt believe your eyes? We want you to experience those feelings again‚Äîor maybe for the first time.

Tapping the Best of the Genre

Far from mindlessly relying on clich√© and formula, The Eternal Life of Goldman turns the genre on its head. item.title: All of a sudden, here's a game where you mix potions for Disney villains
item.content:encoded:
https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/all-of-a-sudden-heres-a-game-where-you-mix-potions-for-disney-villains

When there's as big a brand as Disney, that has enough money to just kind of throw whatever at the wall and see what sticks, eventually you wind up with something that might make you scratch your head a bit. Today, that thing is Disney Villains Cursed Caf√©, a visual novel where you serve a bevy of potions to various Disney baddies, announced earlier today as part of the final Nintendo Direct for the OG Switch (but yes, it is on PC too - in fact it's already out on Steam).

The concept is pretty simple: you are a Potionista, someone that, uh, brews potions, and you run a caf√© frequented by Disney villains from a range of its films. That includes folks like Jafar from Aladdin, Ursula from The Little Mermaid, Gaston from Beauty and the Beast, all of them wearing not exactly casual outfits, but clothing you could see them wearing on the weekend at the very least.

For the most part gameplay looks simple. Brew a potion, serve them to the villain, listen to their stories. As mentioned it's a visual novel, and the emphasis more seems to be about chatting with Disney villains than anything particularly more complex (not to say that visual novel can't be complex, it's just this one doesn't seem to be).

There's just one thing I find a bit icky about it, as has been pointed out by several other people across social media, that being that it kind of seems to be ripping off Coffee Talk. I don't exactly love a giant like the House of Mouse trying to corporate-wash a beloved indie game like that in all honesty. Anyway, Maleficent getting an iPhone is kind of funny I guess.
